title: Lumb Hole Falls Walking Route

images.title: michael ely / Lumb Hole, Crimsworth Dean
images.caption: Lumb Hole, Crimsworth Dean. The highlight of many a walk and picnic. And where six young friends met before being called up to fight in the First World War. They never saw Lumb Hole again.

images.title: Peter Worrell / Ted Hughes Plaque
images.caption: Ted Hughes Plaque Ted Hughes, Poet Laureate, was inspired to write a poem, by an old photograph of six young men taken at this spot near Lumb Bridge. The photograph was of six young men taken just before the FIrst World War. Sadly all the young men lost their lives in that war.

images.title: Raymond Knapman / Lumb Bridge
images.caption: Two walkers take in the view on Lumb Bridge in February

images.title: The bridleway across Crimsworth Dean by Humphrey Bolton, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The bridleway across Crimsworth Dean, just east of the falls.

images.title: michael ely / Crimsworth Dean from Sunny Bank
images.caption: Crimsworth Dean from Sunny Bank. Here we are looking south from the ruined Sunny Bank Farm on Sunny Bank Road, a steep bridleway up the west side of Crimsworth Dean Beck valley. The blip on the skyline is Heptonstall church. This area is located just to the south of the falls.

images.title: Dave.Dunford, CC BY-SA 4.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Wheat Ing Bridge over the Crimsworth Dean Beck, south of the falls.

images.title: South Pennines above Hebden Bridge 2 by Bobby Clegg, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: South Pennines above Hebden Bridge. A view of the countryside surrounding the site.

description: This walk visits a series of waterfalls just to the north of Hebden Bridge . Much of the area surrounding the site is private land so please stick to the public rights of way. You can start the walk from the parking area on Hebden Bridge Road just to the east of the falls at Gib Slack. From here you follow footpaths west for about half a mile to reach the falls at Crimsworth Dean Beck. Here you'll find the rushing falls next to Lumb Bridge. There's also a plaque to Ted Hughes poem 'Six young Men' which concerns a group of men photographed at the falls before they went to fight in the first World War. After admiring the falls you can follow paths running along the beck and through the peaceful woodland, before heading back to the parking area. To continue your walking in the area head to the nearby Hardcastle Crags which are located just to the west of the falls on the Haworth-Hebden Bridge Walk . The National Trust run area is home to tumbling streams, beautiful waterfalls and Gibson Mill.
